answerText: free radicals[10] The selectivity of bromination is explained by this postulate, because the late transition state has strong radical character. This postulate states that a transition state resembles the species closest to it in free energy.
heading: ACF Regionals |2014 | Brown A, Caltech B, and Colonel By | 5 | Science | Chemistry | College
subject: Science
question: Question:  [10] Bromination of an alkane will involve one of these highly reactive species as an intermediate, formed by the homolysis of diatomic bromine. These species have unpaired electrons.
